info: Reference to FY2025 and Cost of Goods and Services Sold tag; no substantive investor-relevant details.

The filing enumerates numerous asset categories—including finance receivables, loans receivable, various government and corporate debt securities, asset‑backed securities, commercial paper, certificates of deposit, private equity funds, and money‑market funds—each associated with specific reporting dates and a disclosed amount (either 858877 or 200000858877), indicating the composition of the investment portfolio.

Filing lists various debt securities, mortgage-backed securities, commercial paper, certificates of deposit, money-market funds, senior notes and other short- and long-term debt, each with a reported fair-value amount of 858877; an initial figure of 70000858877 appears at the start.

The filing lists multiple fixed‑rate notes with interest rates of 5.30%, 5.50% and 5.35% maturing in 2054, 2055 and 2064, alongside various foreign‑exchange, interest‑rate and total‑return swap contracts designated as hedging instruments.

The filing lists multiple compensation plan members—including stock, restricted stock, performance shares, 401(k) plans, and deferred compensation—alongside valuation allowance disclosures and detailed operating segment reporting for the Americas, EMEA, and Asia‑Pacific regions for fiscal years 2022 through 2025.
Legal dispute with a supplier noted.

Cisco, a large accelerated filer and well‑known seasoned issuer, designs and sells networking, security, collaboration and observability technologies and is integrating AI across its product portfolio. The company operates globally in three geographic segments (Americas; EMEA; APJC) and serves a broad customer base. It reports a market value of $247.5 billion and 3,953,196,953 shares outstanding as of August 28 2025.

Cisco emphasizes AI integration across networking, security, collaboration and observability while advancing its One Cisco portfolio (AI‑ready data centers, future‑proofed workplaces, digital resilience). The company highlights its recent acquisition of Splunk to boost security analytics, the introduction of new AI‑ready smart switches (9350, 9610, N9300) and 8000 series routers, and a focus on modern infrastructure, cybersecurity, and observability. Risks noted include dependence on new product development, distribution channel disruptions, inventory complexity, geopolitical and economic uncertainties, and cyber threats. The workforce supporting worldwide sales and marketing totals about 25,600 employees.

Company highlights ongoing acquisition and investment strategy, emphasizes competitive pressures especially price competition from Asian vendors, outlines R&D focus across networking, security, collaboration and observability, notes reliance on contract manufacturers, discusses IP and regulatory risks, and underscores strong talent positioning with ranking #3 in Fortune 2025, 86200 employees and high employee engagement with 2000000 Team Space Check‑Ins in fiscal 2025.

Cisco’s leadership team features recent senior appointments: Ms. Stahlkopf has served as EVP and Chief Legal Officer since August 2021 after 14 years at Microsoft and sits on the NextEra Energy board (since 2023); Mr. Subaiya became EVP of Operations in March 2024 following eight years at Salesforce and now serves on the Genpact board (since 2025); and Mr. Tuszik assumed the EVP of Global Sales role in April 2025, bringing over a decade of experience at Computacenter. The filing also outlines extensive risk factors, highlighting demand volatility, supply‑chain and component shortages, inventory and purchase‑commitment exposures, macro‑economic and geopolitical uncertainty, and the volatile nature of the service‑provider and cloud markets that could materially affect Cisco’s results.

The company warns that its two‑tier distribution model, channel partner financial health, and inventory management could negatively affect revenue and gross margins. Intense competition—including price pressure from Asian vendors and new entrants in SDN, white‑box, AI, cloud and services—poses a threat to market share. Ongoing AI integration and the shift toward software‑as‑a‑service bring regulatory, performance and reputational risks. Recent and future acquisitions (e.g., Splunk) add integration, debt, goodwill‑impairment and other operational risks. Potential restructurings, realignments, and entry into new markets could trigger special charges and operational disruption.

The filing highlights material risks including potential goodwill and intangible impairments, integration challenges from acquisitions, product quality and IP litigation, credit and market risks, exposure to foreign currency, geopolitical and macro‑economic factors, and a sizable debt profile with $24.8 billion senior notes and up to $15 billion commercial paper capacity (with $3.5 billion outstanding).

The company highlights extensive intellectual property risks, including potential challenges to patents, reliance on third‑party licenses, and exposure from acquisitions, as well as significant cybersecurity and privacy threats that could disrupt operations, incur legal liability, or damage reputation. It notes ongoing cyber‑risk management through a dedicated security organization, regular board and audit committee reporting (four times annually with two live presentations), and a chief security officer with over 25 years of experience. Additionally, stock price volatility and evolving global regulatory requirements are identified as material risks.

Cisco reported solid revenue growth of 5% YoY driven by full-year Splunk integration, with product revenue up 6% and services up 3%. Geographic revenue rose notably in the Americas (+$1.7B), EMEA (+$0.7B) and APJC (+$0.5B). Product mix shifted toward Security (+59%) and Observability (+26%) while Networking declined 3%. Gross margin improved modestly, operating margin dipped due to higher amortization and a legal charge, and diluted EPS remained flat. The company continues a large $14.2B stock repurchase authorization, having purchased 19 shares in Q2 2025 at an average $64.65 and retains $15.0M–$14.7M of potential buy‑back value. Shareholder base stood at 30,790 as of Aug 2025. Competitive pressures and trade‑policy complexities persist as Cisco invests in AI‑enabled offerings.

Gross margin modestly rose 0.2 pp overall while product margin matched, offset by legal dispute charges and amortization. R&D, sales & marketing expenses rose 1.8 pp as a share of revenue. Operating income margin fell 1.8 pp. Geographic revenue grew strongly with Americas up $1.7 bn, EMEA $0.7 bn and APJC $0.5 bn; Q4 revenue rose 8% (product +10%). Product revenue grew 6% YoY, led by Security (+59%), Observability (+26%) and Collaboration (+1%) with a 3% drop in Networking. Cash and equivalents fell to $16.1 bn, operating cash flow $14.2 bn, debt decreased to $28.1 bn. Inventory provisions total $493 mn (2025). Effective tax rate declined to 8.3%. No goodwill impairment; fair‑value excesses of $56.5 bn, $80.1 bn and $32.9 bn for Americas, EMEA and APJC respectively. Diluted EPS rose 19% in Q4.

Revenue grew 5% in FY2025 driven by a 6% rise in product sales and 3% rise in services, with growth across all geographic segments. Product revenue increased in the Americas (+6%), EMEA (+4%) and APJC (+7%). By category, Networking declined 3% (‑$925 M), while Security surged 59% (+$3 019 M), Collaboration rose 1% (+$41 M) and Observability climbed 26% (+$218 M). A legal dispute settlement resulted in a GAAP charge to product cost.

Networking revenue fell 3% ($0.9B) due to weaker server and campus switching shipments, while Security surged 59% ($3.0B) on Threat Intelligence and Splunk offerings; Collaboration rose 1% ($41M) and Observability jumped 26% ($218M). Services revenue grew 3% to $15.0B across all regions. Gross margins improved: product margin to 63.7%, services margin to 68.5%, total margin 64.9%, with segment margins rising in Americas, EMEA and APJC. R&D, sales/marketing and G&A expenses increased sharply, with R&D up 16% to $9.3B reflecting AI and headcount investments. Ongoing supply‑chain commitments and a recent legal settlement add exposure to future margins.

R&D, sales and marketing, and G&A expenses rose due to higher headcount, share‑based and cash compensation from acquisitions and discretionary spend, partially offset by lower contracted services and acquisition‑related costs. Foreign‑currency effects cut combined expenses by $16 million. Amortization of purchased intangibles increased on recent acquisitions with impairment charges of $40 million in 2025 versus $145 million in 2024. Restructuring charges were $744 million in 2025 and $789 million in 2024, part of a plan affecting 7% of the workforce with ~$1 billion pre‑tax impact. Operating income fell to $11.76 billion (20.8% of revenue) from $12.18 billion (22.6%) in 2024. Net interest expense turned negative at –$592 million. Other income was –$68 million, driven by investment gains/losses. Effective tax rate dropped to 8.3% from 15.6% after a $720 million tax benefit. Cash and equivalents rose to $8.346 billion and total cash‑and‑investments fell to $16.11 billion, with $6.44 billion paid as dividends and $5.99 billion in share repurchases. Operating cash generated $14.19 billion, yielding free cash flow of $13.29 billion. Dividend per share was $1.62 and 105 million shares were repurchased at $56.53 per share.

Board declared a $0.41 quarterly dividend and retained $14.2 billion of authorized share repurchase capacity. Accounts receivable were flat year‑over‑year at $6.7 billion. Inventories fell 6% to $3.2 billion while inventory purchase commitments rose 47% to $7.6 billion, driven by Silicon One demand. Financing receivables declined 3% to $6.5 billion; channel partner financing volume dropped to $24.9 billion and guarantees total $1.3 billion with $123 million of potential future payments. Senior notes outstanding increased to $24.75 billion after a $5 billion issuance in Feb 2025. Commercial paper balances fell to $3.5 billion. Remaining performance obligations grew 6% to $43.5 billion, with product and services components up 8% and 5% respectively.

Performance obligations rose 6% in FY2025 (product up 8% and services up 5%) with about half expected to be recognized as revenue over the next 12 months. Deferred revenue increased 1% FY2025, driven by a 2% rise in product deferrals linked to recurring software, while service deferrals were flat. Total contractual obligations reached $47.8 billion, comprising $24.8 billion of long‑term debt, $1.7 billion of operating leases and $7.6 billion of purchase commitments. The company affirmed sufficient liquidity for the next year. Market risk disclosures note that a 50 bps interest‑rate shift would change the fair value of financing receivables by $0.1 billion and fixed‑rate debt by $0.8 billion. Marketable equity securities fell to $383 million from $481 million, and privately held investments grew to $1.9 billion from $1.8 billion.

The company reported $24.8 billion of senior fixed‑rate notes outstanding (carrying $24.6 billion, fair value $25.0 billion) with a 50 bps rate shift moving fair value by about $0.8 billion. Marketable equity securities fell to $383 million from $481 million a year earlier, while privately held investments rose to $1.9 billion from $1.8 billion. Foreign‑exchange forward contracts show purchased notional amounts of $4.498 billion (2025) and $3.586 billion (2024) with modest fair‑value offsets, and sold contracts of $4.480 billion (2025) and $3.848 billion (2024). Currency fluctuations reduced combined R&D, sales, marketing and G&A expenses by $16 million (0.1%).

Revenue for fiscal 2025 was $56.7 billion, driven by $41.6 billion of product sales and $15.0 billion of services, with gross margin of $36.8 billion and operating income of $11.8 billion. Net income reached $10.2 billion ($2.56 per diluted share). The balance sheet showed strong liquidity with $8.3 billion cash, $7.8 billion investments and total assets of $122.3 billion, while goodwill remained high at $59.1 billion. Management reported effective internal controls and auditors highlighted revenue recognition as a critical audit matter.

Operating cash flow rebounded to $14.2 billion in FY2025, though down from $19.9 billion in FY2023; investing cash turned positive at $1.7 billion after multiyear outflows, while financing cash was a large outflow of $15.8 billion driven by $6.0 billion of share repurchases, $22.1 billion of debt repayments and steady $6.4 billion dividends. Net income fell to $10.2 billion in FY2025 from $12.6 billion in FY2023. Shares outstanding declined to 3.96 billion, common stock and APIC rose to $47.7 billion and total equity to $46.8 billion. Dividend per share modestly increased to $1.62.

Depreciation and amortization expense remained steady at roughly $0.7 billion for fiscal 2023‑2025. Advertising expenses were $205 million, $210 million and $186 million for FY2023, FY2024 and FY2025 respectively. The company emphasizes inventory valuation at the lower of cost or net realizable value with write‑downs tied to demand forecasts, and monitors non‑marketable equity investments for impairment. Credit risk is managed via internal ratings and allowances, with past‑due financing receivables flagged at 31 days and non‑accrual status after 120 days. Lease portfolios include varied asset lives (e.g., 25‑year building depreciation, up to 15‑year improvements, 5‑year equipment/software, 5‑year furniture) and average lease receivable terms of four years.

Security software licenses are treated as a single performance obligation with revenue recognized ratably over the contract term. Advertising expenses were $186M, $210M and $205M in FY2025, FY2024 and FY2023. Total revenue was $56.7B, $53.8B and $57.0B for the same periods, driven by networking, security, collaboration and observability product segments and services. Subscription revenue grew to $31.5B in FY2025 from $27.4B in FY2024. Accounts receivable remained at $6.7B each year; credit loss allowances shifted modestly. Contract assets (gross) totaled $3.3B in FY2025 versus $2.8B in FY2024, with net unbilled receivables of $3.2B and $2.7B. Deferred revenue stood at $28.8B and $28.5B. Capitalized contract acquisition costs were $1.5B and $1.3B, amortized at $957M, $742M and $723M. FY2025 acquisitions involved $293M purchase consideration, $121M intangible assets and $193M goodwill; FY2024 acquisitions (including Splunk) totaled $28.5B purchase consideration, $10.6B intangible assets and $20.2B goodwill.

Cisco completed a $27 billion cash‑and‑stock acquisition of Splunk, adding $19.3 billion of goodwill and $10.6 billion of intangible assets, contributing roughly $1.4 billion of revenue and a $557 million net loss since integration. Transaction costs totaled $82 million ($79 million in FY 2024). Pro‑forma combined revenue is $56.8 billion for FY 2024 (down from $60.8 billion FY 2023) with pro‑forma net income of $9.3 billion versus $10.1 billion. Additional smaller acquisitions added $1.4 billion of consideration in FY 2024 and $315 million in FY 2023. Compensation expenses related to acquisitions are $876 million (2025), $618 million (2024) and $222 million (2023), with up to $618 million of future cash compensation possible. Transaction costs were $104 million in FY 2024, $26 million in FY 2023 and $12 million in FY 2025.

Cisco reported net purchased intangible assets of $9.175 billion in 2025 versus $11.193 billion in 2024, with impairment charges of $40 million in fiscal 2025 and $145 million in fiscal 2024. Amortization of these intangibles was $2.202 billion in 2025, $1.653 billion in 2024 and $0.931 billion in 2023. Future amortization expense is projected at $9.175 billion through 2030. Restructuring charges totaled $744 million in fiscal 2025, $654 million in fiscal 2024 and $670 million in fiscal 2023, with the FY2025 plan targeting up to $1 billion in pre‑tax costs. Cash and cash equivalents rose to $8.346 billion in 2025 from $7.508 billion in 2024, while total inventories were $3.164 billion versus $3.373 billion. Net property and equipment was $2.113 billion in 2025 versus $2.090 billion in 2024. Remaining performance obligations grew to $43.533 billion in 2025, with deferred revenue of $28.779 billion and unbilled contract revenue of $14.754 billion.

The company reported a reduction in transition tax payable after a favorable court opinion, sizable operating lease obligations with ROU assets of $1.301 billion and total lease liabilities of $1.550 billion, and increased lease expenses ($763 million) versus prior year. Lease income declined from $73 million in 2023 to $37 million in 2025, while interest income from lease receivables grew to $66 million in 2025. Financing receivables net to $6.527 billion, split between loan and lease components, with current portions of $3.061 billion. Future minimum lease payments on operating leases total $1.748 billion through 2030 and thereafter.

Cisco's financing receivables declined to $6,511 million in FY2025 from $6,712 million in FY2024, driven by lower loan and lease balances. Past‑due loan amounts fell modestly and non‑accrual and impaired balances decreased. The credit loss allowance was reduced to $50 million from $65 million, reflecting lower provisions and recoveries.

Credit loss allowances fell to $50 M total in 2025 from $65 M in 2024, reflecting lower loan and lease risk; provisions and recoveries turned negative. Available‑for‑sale debt holdings rose to $10.2 B amortized cost (fair value $9.9 B) in 2024‑25, with modest unrealized losses. Marketable equity securities declined to $383 M in 2025 with net unrealized gains of $108 M, down from $481 M and $71 M in 2024. Private‑company investments grew to $1.9 B with $0.3 B unfunded commitments, capping exposure near $2.2 B.

The company reported $7.473 billion of available‑for‑sale debt at amortized cost and $7.381 billion at fair value, with most maturing within five years. Marketable equity securities were $383 million in 2025 (down from $481 million in 2024) and generated $108 million of unrealized gains for the year. Privately held company investments total $1.9 billion (up from $1.8 billion) with $0.3 billion of funding commitments and $0.6 billion measured under the alternative method; net adjustments to these holdings were negative. The firm holds $0.7 billion in private‑equity fund interests and $0.8 billion in variable‑interest entities, with noncontrolling interests of $162 million. Fair‑value assets include $5.885 billion of money‑market funds and senior notes fair value of $25 billion (carrying $24.6 billion) versus $20.4 billion a year earlier. Short‑term debt totals $5.232 billion in 2025 (down from $11.341 billion in 2024), comprising $1.749 billion of senior notes and $3.482 billion of commercial paper, within a $15 billion financing program.

The company maintains a $15 billion commercial‑paper program and issued $5 billion of senior notes in February 2025. As of July 26 2025 it had $24.6 billion of long‑term debt and $20.1 billion of short‑term debt, with $1.75 billion due within the next year. A $5 billion revolving credit facility remains undrawn but in covenant compliance. Future principal payments of $24.75 billion are scheduled through 2030 and thereafter. Derivative hedges total $32 million in assets and $64 million in liabilities, with no material credit‑risk losses anticipated.

The company reported modest gains/losses from fair‑value hedges on interest‑rate derivatives, while non‑designated foreign‑currency derivatives contributed a net gain of $102 million in 2025 versus a $162 million loss in 2024; total‑return swap expenses were $56 million and $91 million respectively. Notional amounts of outstanding derivatives remained high, with foreign‑currency notional of $8.978 billion in 2025 and $7.434 billion in 2024. Purchase‑commitment liabilities decreased to $206 million in 2025 from $498 million in 2024, with total commitments of $7.599 billion versus $5.158 billion. Funding commitments stand at $300 million and $200 million. Channel‑partner financing volumes were $24.9 billion in FY2025, $27.1 billion in FY2024 and $32.1 billion in FY2023, with guarantees outstanding of $1.3 billion and $1.2 billion. Maximum potential future guarantee payments are $123 million (2025) and $127 million (2024). Brazilian tax authorities assert $141 million in taxes, $816 million in interest and $289 million in penalties, though outcomes remain uncertain. Ongoing patent litigations continue but are not expected to materially impact financial statements.

The company notes ongoing patent litigations with uncertain outcomes but expects any damages to be immaterial. It maintains a $14.2 billion authorized stock repurchase program, having repurchased 105 million shares for $5.995 billion in FY2025 (with $20 million pending settlement). A quarterly dividend of $0.41 per share was declared. The 2005 Stock Incentive Plan authorizes 100 million shares, and the Employee Stock Purchase Plan issued 18 million, 20 million and 19 million shares in FY2025‑23 respectively, with 50 million shares remaining. Share‑based compensation expense totaled $3.641 billion in FY2025, $3.074 billion in FY2024 and $2.353 billion in FY2023.

Cisco reported performance‑based RSU grants of 4, 3 and 2 million shares for FY2025‑23 with grant‑date fair values of 54.5, 59.31 and 40.44 respectively. Employee stock purchase right assumptions show volatility around 22‑29%, risk‑free rates 2.8‑5.0%, dividend yields 3.3‑3.6% and fair values 12.18‑12.40. 401(k) matching contributions totaled 373, 358 and 342 million for FY2025‑23. Deferred compensation liability stands at roughly 1,200 million (2025) and 1,100 million (2024). AOCI balances shifted to a net loss of 954 million in 2025. Total income‑tax provision was 920 million in 2025, up from 1,914 million (2024) and 2,705 million (2023); the company recorded a 720 million tax benefit from a court opinion in 2025 and IRS settlements yielding 145 million (2023) and 55 million (2024). Unrecognized tax‑benefit balances were 2,337 million, 2,156 million and 2,137 million for FY2025‑23.

The company eliminated $1.1 billion of gross unrecognized tax benefits in FY23 and $245 million in FY24 after an IRS audit, leaving $1.6 billion that could affect the effective tax rate and estimating a possible $250 million reduction in the next year; net interest expense was modest ($77 million FY25) and total interest‑and‑penalty accruals were $497 million FY25, $401 million FY24 and $523 million FY23; net deferred tax assets amounted to $7.281 billion FY25 and $6.186 billion FY24 after valuation allowances (which saw a $33 million addition FY25), with large NOL and tax‑credit carryforwards still largely offset by allowances; segment revenue rose to $56.654 billion FY25 (Americas $33.656 billion, EMEA $14.824 billion, APJC $8.174 billion) and gross margin increased to $38.938 billion, driven by networking product revenue of $28.304 billion, while long‑lived assets totalled $3.414 billion.

The company reported no customer accounted for 10% or more of revenue, indicating diversified sales. Long-lived assets were $3.414 billion in FY2025, modestly up from $3.156 billion in FY2024, with U.S. assets comprising the majority. Net income fell to $10.18 billion in FY2025 from $10.32 billion in FY2024, driving basic EPS down to $2.56 from $2.55 and diluted EPS to $2.55 from $2.54, while FY2023 levels were higher. A settlement with a supplier released $563 million of escrow cash and forfeited $450 million of prepayments, incurring a $355 million product‑cost charge offset by an $82 million tax benefit. Executive Vice President Oliver Tuszik adopted a 10b5‑1 trading plan to sell about 49,067 shares through year‑end 2025.
The filing incorporates many exhibits, notably a merger agreement dated September 20, 2023, and multiple indenture and note filings from 2009 through 2025 covering various senior notes issuances.
The filing includes a list of exhibits and the signatures of Cisco’s senior officers and directors, with the report signed on September 3, 2025.
